data.title: Love for Catch-22 by Joseph Heller
data.meta_description: During times of uncertainty and turmoil, surrounding ourselves with our best artwork will soothe and inspire. The novel Catch-22 by Joseph Heller is ranked #7 of all time. The novel is a satirical look at the follies and abuses of war and capitalism.
data.text:
I finished reading Catch-22 by Joseph Heller. I don’t think I’ve ever read a funnier novel or more devilishly detailed characterization. It’s ranked #7 on Modern Library’s Top 100 Novels list.

The novel satirizes war and the dismissive attitude toward human life that war, by its very nature, encourages. The war machine takes over until there’s nothing human left. Pushing absurdities to the limit. It’s the kind of humor that spotlights horror.

I’m obsessed with satire. What a gift to be able to make people laugh AND drive home a larger message. I’m working on a novel that I think is ripe for satire, but hoo boy, I’m intimidated to even try it. I’m trying to convince myself to be brave.

Heller spent 7 years on the novel.

Fun Fact: Catch-22 was originally named Catch-18. Check out this inside look at the title change from The Atlantic between Heller and his editor, Gottlieb:

The “major, major idiom” phrase at the end is a reference to one of the characters in the novel, Major Major.
